Award.AwardTitle: Workshops: Finding your inner modeler: how computational biology can advance your research and how to get started; June/July, 2017-2019; Chicago, Illinois

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
With ever increasing frequency, cell biology researchers are finding the value in predictive computational modeling. Such an approach is a significant step in identifying and confirming the rules that govern life. A current limitation in this approach is a lack of training in the necessary methodology. The purpose of the proposed workshop/conferences is to bring together researchers who seek training in computational methods with those researchers that have this expertise. The expected outcome of this work will be to increase the number of cell biological researchers who have expertise in computational methods and who can, in turn, further increase the number of laboratories in the country who are familiar with these modern computational methods.

The effort will involve a sequence of workshops that are designed to provide training in computational modeling methods to novices. Prior to the first meeting the participants will be asked to prepare for the meeting, both in preparing short statement of their own modeling interests, along with reading selected papers. During the first workshops, the novices will be paired with experienced modelers who will help develop a collaborative workplan for the following year. In subsequent meeting in years 2 and 3, the teams will come together and present their results and obtain feedback from the group, which will guide further computational work on their respective projects. The expected outcome will be the development of productive collaborations along with the training of more researchers who can carry out computational modeling in the field of cell biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of cell biology has reached a pivotal stage. Many biological processes involve myriad molecular players whose interactions and activities change rapidly in both time and space. To extract the principles underlying these processes from what are often large and complex datasets requires computational modeling, a synthesis of mathematical tools and computer algorithms. Although productive interdisciplinary collaborations are becoming more common, many in the cell biology community are not yet using computational approaches. These cell biologists fall into three groups. Some question the value of computational modeling in their research. Others are interested, but do not think they have enough data to begin. Still others simply do not know how to start. To address these concerns, two specialized workshops were held at the University of Illinois at Chicago in the summers of 2017 and 2018. Called the "Finding Your Inner Modeler" (FYIM) workshops, these events had two goals: (1) To stimulate interest in computational modeling among traditional cell biologists by demonstrating its utility, by illustrating how computational models are built and how their output is appropriately interpreted, and by debunking widespread misconceptions about these and related topics; (2) To catalyze the formation of interdisciplinary collaborations between traditional cell biologists and expert modelers in other fields who are interested in working on biological problems. These FYIM workshops were the first with the expressed purpose of edifying traditional cell biologists as to why, when, and how to employ computational modeling in their research, while providing both cell biologists and computational modelers with in-person and online opportunities to form collaborations. Previously sponsored NSF workshops have targeted quantitative cell biologists who were already engaged in computational modeling. Approximately 200 scientists, representing all career stages and all demographics, participated in the two workshops. In post-meeting surveys, over 90% of the attendees indicated that they considered the workshops a valuable use of their time and would recommend future such events to their colleagues.
